loan.use: to purchase more products such as can goods, dry goods, and home products

loan.name: Dianalina

texts.en:
Dianalina is 26 years old and married. She has a 3-year-old child. Her husband is a fisherman.
Dianalina is a seaweed farmer. She cultivates seaweed and sells it to buyers at her town. She also sells her husbands catch at her towns market. Dianalina needs materials for seaweed farming such as, straw and bamboo sticks. She has requested a loan so she can continue her business. Dianalina hopes for this loan to help improve her business.

loan.use: to purchase materials for seaweed farming such as straw and bamboo sticks

loan.name: Art

texts.en: Art, 37, resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia. Art is a housewife while her husband is employed to break stones into pieces to sell, earning an income of USD 10 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 123 on food and USD 25 on other necessary expenses. Art is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a plot of farmland to improve her family farming. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loan.use: to buy a plot of farmland

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To buy clothing for her business

loan.name: Ith

texts.en:
Ith, 45, resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in the country. Ith is a housewife, while two of her children are employed at a factory, earning an income of $2 US each per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $25 on food and $25 on other necessary expenses.
Ith is requesting a loan of $1000 to finish the construction of her house. This will be her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loan.use: to finish her construction of her house

loan.name: Erna

texts.en:
Erna is a 41-year-old married woman with three children. The oldest child is 16 years old.
Erna has been in the business of raising hogs for two years. She plans to user her loan to buy pig feed and vitamins. Each month, Erna earns 4000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from her hog-raising business.
In the future, Erna hopes to have a stable business that would help her sustain her children's education.

loan.use: to buy pig feed and vitamins

loan.name: Big

texts.en:
Big, 58, resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions the country.
Big is a housewife while her three children are employed at the factory, earning an income of $2 US each per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $25 on food and $25 on the other necessary expenses.
Big is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase fabrics to resell. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loan.use: to buy fabrics to resell

loan.name: Batzorig

texts.en:
Batzorig is a 23-year-old single man who lives with his parents in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Batzorigs mother is unemployed and looks after the household, and his father works in local council as a water distributor, distributing fresh water to slum district households.
Batzorig runs a taxi business using his family's car. To run a taxi business without a warm garage is impossible, especially in the winter, because during winter nights cars freeze and people always have trouble starting them.
Last year Batzorig started building a warm garage for his car and at the moment the basement is completed. The loan Batzorig is taking out will be used to complete the garage building project with the purchase of bricks, cement, and a garage door.

loan.use: to buy bricks, cement, and a garage door and finish an uncompleted garage

loan.name: Kong

texts.en: Mr. Kong, 33, is a resident of Siem Reap Province. He is a domestic farmer and earns an average of $4 a day. He is married to Mrs. Saroun, 30, who is also a farmer. They have three school-aged children. Mr. Kong used to raise pigs in the past but had to stop that activity due to financial problems faced by his family. He now hopes to return to this business by using a Kiva loan to buy pig feed and piglets for breeding. This will provide him with additional income which he will use to better meet his familys needs.

loan.use: buy piglets and pig feed

loan.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida, from the village of Dansalan, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte, is 51 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Adelaida owns and operates a general store in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Adelaida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 3000 PHP to purchase more products such as canned goods, dry goods, and home needs, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase more products such as canned goods, dry goods, and home needs.

loan.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine, from the village of Sto. Nio, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte, is 35 years old, married, and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business venture selling agricultural equipment in the local community. Engaged in her business for over two years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 3000 PHP to purchase more equipment for her enterprise, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase more equipment for her farm supplies business.

location.town: Santo Nio, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte

loan.name: Pea

texts.en: Mrs. Pea, 46, is married to Nem Loy, 56, who catches fresh fish in and around the lakes of his community. Mrs. Pea sells the fresh fish that her husband and other fishermen catch for reasonable prices. Presently, she also sells some merchandise around her village for extra income. Because of her old broken motorbike, her fish selling business has been affected. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Pea is seeking a loan from Kiva to buy a new motorcycle to replace the broken one.

loan.use: buy a new motorcycle.

loan.name: Marciana

texts.en:
Marciana is a married woman with two children. She is 57 years old and has had a sari-sari (variety) store business for six years.
Marciana sells items like sugar, spices and detergent soap to the people in her community. She earns about 4,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) per month with her store. Marciana also provides tailoring services.
Marciana is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP to buy more items to sell, such as canned goods and soap.
In the future, Marciana hopes to have a productive business and successful children.

loan.use: to buy more items to sell, such as canned goods and soap.

loan.name: Tumenjargal

texts.en: Tumenjargal, 43, is married and lives with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They have daughter who is married. The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in the outer ger districts of the city. Tumenjargal graduated from a course with a concentration in tailoring in 1999. Since 2000, she had been sewing the traditional Mongolian robes called deel. Her husband is a herdsman. Tumenjargal supports her family by operating her handmade clothing business. She usually sews deels to sell them in Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. She purchases her materials for handmade clothing from Narantuul. Tumenjargal is requesting a loan of 700,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) to purchase more deel materials to sew deels before the Mongolian national celebration, called Naadam, because the demand for deel rises during this celebration. Tumenjargal wants to improve her business with this loan and then be able to build her own small house.

loan.use: to purchase more materials to sew Mongolian traditional robes.

loan.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is from the village of San Roque, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 48 years old. Merlinda is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Merlinda makes and sells food. Merlinda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 1,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.
In 2010, Merlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC.
Merlinda is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients for her snack-vending business. This will be the second loan taken out by Merlinda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.
The setting on the digital camera had the incorrect date, so the photo appears to have been taken earlier than it actually was taken.
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase raw ingredients for her snack-vending business.

location.town: San Roque, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte

loan.name: Narankhuu

texts.en:
Mrs. Narankhuu is a 53-year-old widow. She lives with her youngest sons family in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She has four children; the three eldest ones are married and live with their families. She owns a small land plot and a house on it. Her youngest son, Batjargal, runs a small workshop to repair digital cameras.
Mrs. Narankhuu has been on her pension since 2008. Last year, she started to renovate her house but could not finish it due to the coming wintertime and shortage of money. The loan she is taking will be used to buy necessary building materials to complete the unfinished renovation to her family house.

loan.use: to buy necessary building materials to complete the unfinished renovation to her family house.

loan.name: Ryskan's Group

texts.en: Ryskan is the leader of this group. She is 25 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband, she brings up a daughter and a son. Both children are preschool age (under seven). Ten years ago, Ryskan sold vegetables which were grown in her garden. She saved 5,000 soms and with that money she purchased cattle for breeding. In order to earn money to meet the family needs, Ryskan breeds cattle for resale at a higher price. With money from this loan, she wants to purchase a calf for breeding. In the future, Ryskan wants to save money to purchase a vehicle. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young and ambitious socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase a calf.

loan.name: Erna

texts.en:
Erna is 48 years old. She is married and has 2 children. She earns a living by raising pigs, goats, chickens and ducks in the Philippines. Erna has been raising livestock for 15 years and also earns additional income from selling feeds.
Erna is borrowing PHP 29500 through NWTF to purchase additional livestock, feeds and vitamins. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future for her family.

loan.use: purchase livestock, feeds and vitamins

loan.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina is from the village of Lumbayao, Tampilisan, Zamboanga Sibugay. She is 46 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Josefina owns & operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector operating a furniture-making business in the local community.Josefina has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2011, Josefina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josefina is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials for her furniture making business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Josefina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase raw materials for her furniture making business

loan.name: Hong

texts.en:
Mrs. Hong is a 49-year-old married woman and mother of three children, one of whom is employed as a garment factory worker. She lives with other family members in her own small family home in Kompong Cham Province.
Mrs. Hong owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother where she grows different kinds of crops such as rice, potato, and peanut. She harvests and sells them when they are mature. Her husband works growing these crops with her. Mrs. Hong would like a loan to lease her neighbors land to plant potatoes and to buy insecticides and fertilizers for her crops.

loan.use: lease farm land and buy farm inputs

loan.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is a 42-year-old married woman living in Trinidad, Bohol. She sells fish for a living. Her husband is a fisherman, and she is the one who sells all his catch at the market. Marissa also buys and resells seafood such as crabs and prawns.
Marissa is asking a loan to buy fishing nets, hooks and other fishing gears. She will also buy more seafood to resell. The loan will help Marissa continue her fishing business.

loan.use: to buy fishing nets, hooks and other fishing gears

loan.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace is 36 years old. She is single and has 1 child. She works hard to provide for her family.
Mary Grace runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has been running this business for 9 years. She also earns extra income from pig fattening and fishing. She has requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell such as sardines, groceries, etc. She has successfully repaid 5 previous loans from NWTF before this loan.
Mary Grace aspires to save money to expand her business.

loan.use: buy items to sell in her store

loan.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 42 years old. She is married and has 5 children and works hard to provide for her family.
Erlinda runs a Sari-sari store in the Philippines and has been running this business for 10 years. She also earns extra income from buying and selling rice.
Erlinda has requested a PHP 29500 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks to sell in her sari-sari store. She has successfully repaid 21 previous loans from NWTF before this loan. She aspires to save to expand her business.

loan.use: buy stocks for her store

loan.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma is 21 years old. She is married and has 1 child. She works very hard to provide for her family.
Elma runs a Sari-sari store in the Philippines and has been in this business for 2 years. She sells a veriety of items such as coffee, cream, sugar, etc.
Elma has requested a PHP 14000 loan through NWTF to buy more stocks to sell like sardines and other grocery items. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loan.use: buy more stocks to sell

loan.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica is a married woman with 5 children. She is 46 years old and has had a sari-sari store business for 5 years.
Veronica sells items like canned goods to the people in her community. She usually earns about 4,000 PHP per month through her sari-sari store. Veronica also raises pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them at the market.
Veronica is requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP to buy more items, such as noodles and spices, to sell. She also plans to buy feeds and vitamins for the pigs. Veronica hopes to have a stable business.

loan.use: to buy more items to sell, such as noodles and spices

loan.name: Hariet

texts.en:
Hariet is 36 years old. She is married and has 5 children. Hariet works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has been running this business for 13 years. She also earns income from a piggery and a rice mill.
Hariet has requested a PHP 29000 loan through NWTF to purchase stocks to sell, such as sardines and other grocery items. She has successfully repaid 13 loans from NWTF before this loan. She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loan.use: buy stocks to sell

loan.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fruit and vegetable vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 7 years. She also earns additional income from food vending. She is borrowing PHP 19500 through NWTF to purchase more stocks of fruits and vegetables to sell.
Luz has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to repair and renovate her family home in the future.

loan.use: buy fruits & vegetables to sell

loan.name: Babi Rahayu Group

texts.en:
Babi Rahayu Group has received its third loan from MUK. Ni Ketut, as head of the group, obtained a loan of 1,500,000 Indonesian rupiah, used to maintain two pigs that will be prepared to be sows. Ni Ketut finds it helpful to supplement family income with this work. She hopes for the future this cooperative will run smoothly. Furthermore, with the present value of pork starting to improve, these loans will be very useful.
Ni Ketut is in the front row, third from left, wearing brown clothing. Of the total number of members (14), only 13 could be present because there was a religious ceremony.

loan.use: to buy two pigs.

loan.name: Kanymbu's Group

texts.en:
Kanymbu is the leader of this group. She is 53 and married to an electrician. Together with her husband, she has raised three sons and a daughter. All the children are married and live separately with their families. And under the Kyrgyz traditions the youngest son lives with the parents. In order to contribute money to family budget Kanymbu takes orders and sews Kyrgyz national cloth, blankets and pillows. In this way, she earns 3000 soms per month. The family also breeds livestock for making additional money. Kanymbu hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future she dreams of building a big house for the family.
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase livestock

loan.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia is 43 years old and widowed. She has 2 children.
Sylvia works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 25000 loan through NWTF to buy inventory to sell like sugar, groceries, etc. in her sari-sari store.
Sylvia has borrowed and repaid 12 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 15 years. She also earns an income from buying and selling rice grains.
Sylvia aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loan.use: to buy inventory to sell in her sari-sari store.

loan.name: Violeta

texts.en:
As a married parent of 4 children, Violeta works hard to support her family. She has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from operating a piggery. Violeta is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell for her vegetable vending business.
Violeta has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loan.use: to buy more vegetables to sell.

loan.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita is 30 years old. She is married and has 2 children. Amelita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 19500 loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell in her sari-sari store.
Amelita has borrowed and repaid 13 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 9 years and also earns an income from buying and selling copra (coconut meat) . Amelita aspires to save money to expand her business.

loan.use: to purchase items to sell in her sari-sari store.

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 56 years old. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 18000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like milk, sugar, etc. in her general store.
Gloria has borrowed and repaid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 2 years and also earns an income from raising pigs, rice and feed retailing.
Gloria aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loan.use: to buy additional inventory to sell.

loan.name: Ma. Daty

texts.en:
Ma. Daty is 43 years old. She is married and has 2 children. Ma. Daty works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 28000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store.
Ma. Daty has borrowed and repaid 19 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for 15 years and also earns an income from buying and selling seaweeds and livestock. Ma. Daty aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loan.use: to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store.

loan.name: Maria Elena

texts.en: As a widowed mother of three children, Maria Elena works hard to support her family by selling used clothing and ready-to-wear clothes in the Philippines. Maria Elena has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF and is now requesting a new loan of PHP 25000 to purchase more bundles of used clothes. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream of building and expanding her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loan.use: to purchase bundles of used clothing to sell.

loan.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling fruits and vegetables in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 22 years, and earns additional income from a sari-sari store, as well as from the buying and selling of charcoal.
Nenita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of loans from NWTF. She is borrowing 19,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase more stock of fruits and vegetables to sell. She dreams of saving enough money so she can one day afford to send her children to college.

loan.use: to purchase more stock of fruits and vegetables.

loan.name: Normalyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of 3 children, Normalyn works hard to support her family. She has a business buying and selling seaweed (goso) in the Philippines, and also earns additional income providing manicures & pedicures.
Normalyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 5 loans from NWTF. She is now borrowing 16,000 PHP through NWTF to buy more seaweed to sell. She hopes that her hard work will help her achieve her dream of saving enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loan.use: to buy more seaweed (goso) to sell.

loan.name: Rhyjil

texts.en:
Rhyjil, 27, is a rice farmer from the town of Sta. Josefa Agusan Del Sur. She has been into this business for 9 years.
The loan that she took from Community Economic Ventures Inc. will help her pay the farm inputs such as seed and labor. Aside from financing a farm, she plans to buy feed for her pigs.
Rhyjil has two children. Her eldest child is 9 years old while her youngest child is only 4. Her dream in the future is to send all her children to college.

loan.use: to purchase seeds, pay for labor and buy pig feeds

loan.name: Nuon

texts.en:
There are many Cambodians who make a living as rice cultivators; one of them is Mrs. Nuon, who has been working in this sector since 2000. She and her husband grow rice on their own farmland that they inherited from their grandparents. From this business they generate an income of around US $3 per day. This humble couple have four children, one of whom is working in manufacturing as a sewing worker and earns a fixed salary every month.
Mrs. Nuon would like to apply for a loan to buy two cows to support her in the field.

loan.use: to buy two cows to support her in the field.

loan.name: Marieme

texts.en:
As a married parent of 4 children, Marieme works hard to support her family. She has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from food vending and selling coconut wine.
Marieme has been sustaining her business activities through her past loans from NWTF. She is now borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase spare parts for motorcycle maintenance. She hopes that her hard work will help her achieve her dream of saving money to expand her business and send her children to college.

loan.use: to purchase spare parts for motorcycle maintenance.

loan.name: Rizalina

texts.en:
Rizalina is 49 years old, married, and has 1 child. She works hard to provide for her family. She has been running a sari-sari store in the Philippines for 20 years, and earns additional income from a cafeteria, rice retailing and farming.
Rizalina has borrowed and paid back loans from NWTF before, and has now requested a 25,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc in her store. She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loan.use: to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store.

loan.name: Enebish

texts.en:
Mrs. Enebish is 31 years old. She lives with her husband and two children in Erdenet, the third largest city of Mongolia. Erdenet is famous for its copper production. Her two children are both studying at university.
Enebishs husband, Boldchuluun, is a plumber and works for a construction company.
Since 2002, Mrs.Enebish has been running a tailoring business. She makes new dresses by customers order and also fixes dresses. Last year, she started a building project to build a family house and the project is 70 percent complete. The project was stopped due to the winter season and shortage of money, and now she is planning to finish the building project.
The loan she is asking for will be used to buy building materials such as cement, sand, plaster, laminated floor, main entrance and internal doors and bricks to complete the family's house-building project.

loan.use: To buy building materials such as cement, sand, plaster, laminated floor, main entrance and internal doors and bricks to complete the family's house-building project.

loan.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio is 39 years old and lives in the community of Sta. Josefa, Agusan Del Sur. He is a rice farmer and a piggery owner. He has been in these businesses for 11 years. His monthly income from his businesses is PHP 4,000.
With a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc., he will buy farm and agricultural supplies such as seeds and fertilizers. He will also buy pig feed and pay school fees for his children.
Rogelio has two children. His dream is to become successful in his swine fattening and rice farm businesses.

loan.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and pig feed

loan.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 63 years old and married. She is from the town of Sta. Josefa Agusan del Sur. She has been a farmer for 10 years already.
Through a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc., she hopes to buy fertilizers and insecticides for her rice farm and feed for her livestock.
Teresita has eight children. In the future, she dreams of being able to support the needs of her family and children.

loan.use: to buy fertilizers, insecticides and feed

loan.name: Unisa

texts.en: This is 36 year-old Unisa. He is married, and has two children aged 2 and 4 years old. In 2007, Unisa established his provisions and drinks business. He began his business to help him provide a livelihood for his family. Working 7 days a week and 15 hours a day, he earns about Le 700,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan of Le 4,000,000 to buy more provisions such as milk, sugar, margarine and soft drinks for his business. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 200,000. In the future, Unisa plans to buy a piece of land and educate his children to college level. He thanks you for your support.

loan.use: To buy more provisions such as milk, sugar, margarine and soft drinks for his business.

loan.name: Aigul's Group

texts.en: Aigul is the leader of this group. She is 37 and married to a welder. Together they bring up a daughter, who is 13 and studies at school. Two years ago, with an initial investment of 5000 soms, Aigul purchased socks and started to sell in the Dordoi market (Dordoi is one of the biggest markets in Central Asia). In this way, she earns 8,000 soms per month. This profit made it possible to improve the familys living conditions. With money received from this loan, Aigul wants to purchase a variety of clothes for resale. In the future she wishes to expand her business and provide her daughter with a good education. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young and ambitious socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase clothes.

loan.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida is 33 years old and is a married woman from the town of Sta. Josefa Agusan Del Sur. She has a small rice farm, which she has been managing for 11 years. Her husband is a farmer. Together they work hard to be able to raise their four children.
With a loan from CEVI, she has easily bought farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. Aside from having a rice field, she also raises pigs.
In the future, she hopes to manage a bigger farm and a piggery so that she will be able to fund the education of her children.

loan.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loan.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is from the village of Villaflor, Oroquieta City. She is 41 years old, married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Imelda runs a general store in the local community. Imelda has been engaged in her business for 12 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities. Imelda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC.
Imelda is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP to purchase more products such as canned goods, dry goods, and products needed for home chores. This loan will be the 10th loan taken out by Imelda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase more products such as canned goods, dry goods, and household needs

loan.name: Jirilin

texts.en:
Jirilin is from the village of Antonino, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 24 years old. Jirilin is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Jirilin owns & operates a fishing business harvesting & selling wild-caught fish in the local community. Jirilin has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2011, Jirilin joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jirilin is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jirilin from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loan.name: Kourk

texts.en:
Mrs. Kourk is a 64 year old widowed villager who lives in the Kompong Cham Province. She is the mother of three children, two of whom are sewing workers. Her husband died of senility several years ago.

Mrs. Kourk has been growing crops for a long-time, making a low income of about $1.25 per day to support the family. Presently, her house is too narrow and very old, and she wishes to move to a new place but does not have sufficient funds to do that. Mrs. Kourk is applying for a loan of $550 to buy some land to build her new home.

loan.use: buy land to build a new house.

loan.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina is from the village of Milanid Talinga, Leon B. Postigo. She is 43 years old, married and has five children. To make a living, Sabina operates a business manufacturing charcoal from coconut shells. She is a charcoal maker. Sabina has been engaged in her business for four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. Sabina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Sabina is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase more coconut shells for her charcoal business. This will be the second loan taken out by Sabina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.
About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders

loan.use: To purchase more coconut shells for her charcoal maunfacturing business

location.town: Milanid, Talinga, Leon B. Postigo, Zamboanga del N

loan.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda is 57 years old and married. She lives in the community of Sta. Josefa Agusan del Sur. Her husband is a farmer and a Brgy. Kagawad in their community. For eight years, she and her husband have been tilling their small rice farm to be able to raise their children.
With the loan coming from Community Economic Ventures Inc., she will buy fertilizers and other farm inputs.
Nilda has four children. Her eldest child is 24 and her youngest child is 14. In the future, she hopes to have a bigger farm and more profit for her family.

loan.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm inputs

loan.name: Marjoren

texts.en:
Marjoren is from the village of Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. Marjoren is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marjoren owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marjoren has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2008, Marjoren joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marjoren has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from PMPC. Marjoren is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP to purchase more products such as shampoo, toothpaste and soap. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Marjoren from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase more products such as shampoo, toothpaste and soap

loan.name: Taman Indah Group

texts.en:
Taman Indah group will repay this loan according to mutual agreement and will be re-applying for loans for the next period to MUK.
Ni Wayan is the chairman of the Taman Indah group. Ni Wayan lives with her husband and daughter, who is still in junior high school. Ni Wayan's portion of the current loan is 1,400,000 Indonesian rupiah (IDR). Half of that will be used to buy two piglets for fattening (350,000 IDR each) and the rest to buy the feed. The piglets will be maintained for five months and then be ready for sale.
She hopes from the results of this pig farming that the business will grow. She plans to use the profits to supplement the family's income and repay the loan from MUK.
Ni Wayan is in the front row, second from right, wearing colorful clothing with a flower motif.

loan.use: To buy two piglets for fattening

loan.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is from the village of Binuangan, Sindangan. She is 30 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene buys fish from the fishermen of their barangay and nearby barangays. She lets the fish dry, using the fish nets, under the heat of the sun.
Arlene has been engaged in her business for 2 years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. Arlene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, with which she will purchase more fish. This will be the 15th loan taken out by Arlene from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.
About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative: (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders

loan.use: to buy fresh fish to produce dried fish.

loan.name: Byambatsogt

texts.en:
Mr.Byambatsogt is 41 years old. He lives with his wife and 3 children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family live in their own house in a suburb of Ulaanbaatar. His two eldest children go to University and the youngest one attends a kindergarten. His wife is unemployed at the moment and has been actively looking for a job for the last few months.
Byambatsogt has been running a taxi business, using his family car, since 2005. He also raises pigs. He has 8 pigs at the moment and he is planning to expand his farming business. Recently he found a quite suitable place for selling motor engine oils and he negotiated to rent a kiosk there. His wife is going run the engine oil and cooling liquids retail kiosk. The loan Byambatsogt is taking will be used to stock up engine oil and cooling liquid to sell to customers and, at the same time, will give his wife a chance to earn money.

loan.use: to stock up enough engine oil and cooling liquid and to sell these items to customers. This will also give his wife a chance to earn money.

loan.name: Ny

texts.en:
Ny, 54, resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia. Ny sells vegetables and fish, earning an income of USD 7.50 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family's expenses.
Each month, the family has to spend USD 50 on food and USD 25 on the other necessary expenses. Ny is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a plot of farmland to improve her family's farming business. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loan.use: to buy a plot of farmland to improve her family's farming business.

loan.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is from the village of Sibula, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old. Gloria is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Gloria owns & operates a fishing business, harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2004, Gloria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase more fish to sell. This will be the 12th loan taken out by Gloria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loan.name: Oun

texts.en:
Oun resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia. Oun is a housewife while her husband is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family's expenses.
Each month, the family has to spend USD 20 on food and USD 25 on the other necessary expenses. Oun is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a plot of farmland to improve her family's farming business. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loan.use: to buy a plot of farmland.

loan.name: Long

texts.en:
From Reussey Keo commune of Phnom Penh City, Mrs. Long is a hard-working woman who has spent her life selling lotus flowers in the Rour Reussey Market. She sells the lotus flowers to people who need it for ceremonies to bless God.

From this business, Mrs. Long can earn a profit of around US$3 every day. She is a widowed woman, currently living with two single children, who are sewing workers. The children often share their profits with Mrs. Long to support the whole familys needs. Mrs. Long is not comfortable, because her house often requires repairs. She would like a loan to repair her old house.

loan.use: repair her old house.

loan.name: Davy

texts.en: Davy, 34, resides in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia, one of the largest rice-producing regions in Cambodia. Davy is a housewife, while her husband is a motorbike repairman earning an income of USD 12 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 70 on food and USD 25 on the other necessary expenses. Davy is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase motorbike spare parts to expand her husbands business. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loan.use: to buy motorbike spare parts to resell.

loan.name: Abu

texts.en:
This is Abu, a 31-year-old married father of two children aged nine years and three months. In 2003, Abu established his used clothing business to generate income to provide for his family. Working 7 days a week and 13 hours a day, he earns about Le 600,000 every month from this business.

Abu would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 to purchase more used clothing for his business and hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 200,000. In the future, Abu plans to educate children to university level and construct a building for his family. He thanks you for your support.

loan.use: to buy more used clothing for his business.

loan.name: Protus

texts.en:
Protus, from the town of Kitale in western Kenya, has been practicing mixed farming for the last four years and sells his milk and eggs to the local market. He mainly depends on the income from his farm to meet the basic needs of his family. Protus faces the challenges of poultry diseases and insufficient poultry feed.

Protus is making his third loan request from Juhudi Kilimo for 40,000 Kes to purchase an additional stock of chickens and construct a poultry house. This loan will improve his production of eggs and earn him more income, thereby enabling him to better provide for the needs of his family. He plans to have 2000 chickens in the next five years and be the main supplier of eggs to the local market.

loan.use: to buy an additional stock of chickens and construct a poultry house.

loan.name: Dulamjav

texts.en:
A resident of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital, 42-year-old Dulamjav lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, with her husband and two daughters, who are 17 and 18 years old. Both of her daughters attend public school. Dulamjavs husband works as an accountant with a local company.

Dulamjav helps support her family by operating three retail stalls at the Narantuul, Mongolia's largest outdoor market, where she sells tools and implements. When she first began her business in 2000, she had 700,000 MNT in working capital and one stall, but she has since expanded and now has 4,000,000 MNT in working capital at her three stalls.

Dulamjav is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to buy more tools and implements to sell to her customers during the busy shopping season ahead. Her main goal for 2011 is to improve her business with this loan and to be able to build her own small house so that her family can enjoy better living conditions.

loan.use: to purchase more tools and implements to sell to her customers.

loan.name: Yeoum

texts.en:
Yeoum resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, one of the largest rice-producing regions in Cambodia. Yeoum is a housewife, while her husband is employed at a hotel, earning an income of USD 3.33 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 30 on food and USD 25 on the other necessities.

Yeoum is requesting a loan of USD 600 to dig a fish pond and to raise fish. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loan.use: to raise fish and dig a fish pond.

loan.name: Kosal

texts.en:
Kosal, 47, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Kosal is a farmer, earning an income of $0.63 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband produces fishing tools to sell, earning an income of $3 per day. Each month, the family has to spend $100 on food and $25 on the other necessary expenses.
Kosal is requesting a loan of $1000 to expand her brother's business by selling and purchasing gold and platinum. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner. Her husband appears in the photograph.

loan.use: to expand her brother's business of gold and platinum purchase and sales

loan.name: Navy

texts.en:
Navy, 47, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Navy and her husband are farmers, earning an income of $1.25 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $75 on food and $25 on the other necessary expenses.
Navy is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to provide transportation services. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loan.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband

loan.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her husband's business of selling garments. He puts the garments on his cart and sells them by visiting different parts of the city. He has been operating this business for the past 10 years.
With the loan, he will buy garments in larger quantities which will help him offer more variety to his customers and earn bigger profits. Naseem is confident about the positive growth of her husband's business and about the better financial future of her family.
She herself is a housewife and stays at home to perform her daily household duties. She is a very active and responsible person and does her duties very responsibly. She has given birth to eight children. Her two elder sons operate an embroidery business; the other four are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education and stay at home.

loan.use: To buy garments in bulk for resale
